Buffers/What-is-a-buffer.title: What is a buffer?
Buffers/What-is-a-buffer.content:
What is a buffer?
A buffer is defined as a region of memory that holds the data for an image to be displayed on a screen. Think of it as a ‚Äòscreen‚Äô. Vizzy has two buffer types.
Screen buffer
This is the buffer that everything gets eventually rendered to by default in Vizzy.
While this is not shown to you, every layer is its own buffer (to allow for effects), but all of their outputs eventually become composited to this screen buffer.


                  
                  Did you know? 
                  
                

When you turn 3D mode on, you are seeing all layer buffers at the same time, which is why they don‚Äôt obscure each other.


Layer buffer
This is a buffer that gets created when you render a layer to a buffer. Every layer will have its own layer buffer. It allows items and effects (even in other layers!) to use the image output of this buffer.


                  
                  Warning! 
                  
                

Rendering a layer to a buffer stops it from being rendered to the screen, which means you have to render it yourself using the Image item, the Transform effect, a custom shader or the Render layer effect.
You should never leave buffers not rendered or hanging!

Effects/What-is-an-effect.title: What is an effect?
Effects/What-is-an-effect.content:
What is an effect?
Known issues


                  
                  Alpha bug 
                  
                

Some effects will cause a confusion between dark colors and transparency, effectively creating unintended blending. You can sometimes remedy this by adding another effect on top - many advanced users choose to add the Crop effect and set all of its values to 0




                  
                  Duplicate bug 
                  
                

Sometimes, especially in heavier projects, when adding an effect it might get added twice.
IMPORTANT: Manually delete one of the effects. Do not reorder it!
If you do not do that, there is a high likelihood that your project will break on the next load.

Introduction/Concepts.title: Concepts
Introduction/Concepts.content:
üí≠ Concepts
When we refer to the editor, we mean this page
When we refer to the community page or creations page, we mean this page
Vizzy is a big program with a lot of features. We have many types of things that can be present in the editor. Here are some of them:

Item - anything that produces an image
Layer - a collection of items
Effect - a post-processing node applied to layers or the composition
Composition - an object holding all of the layers
Object - everything you can interact with is an object
Analyzer - an object providing other objects with audio data
Automation - an object that can change other objects‚Äô controller values

The hierarchy of the objects looks something like this:

Composition

Layers

Items

Controllers

Automations




Layer Effects
Transform controls


Global effects



Layers, Effects and Automations are hierarchical:

Layers get covered by other layers on top of them in the composition
Effects get covered by other effects that are lower in the effects list
Automations are covered by other automations that are lower in the automations list, which means you can have a longer automation be interrupted by a shorter one if it is lower in the list



                  
                  Did you know? 
                  
                

The Layer hierarchy used to be first-to-last, not last-to-first, but it did not match common video editing applications, so we changed it

Introduction/How-Vizzy-Works.title: How Vizzy Works
Introduction/How-Vizzy-Works.content:
‚öôÔ∏è How Vizzy Works
Vizzy is a bit different from many other online video creation tools. Here‚Äôs the magic behind it:
Local rendering
Vizzy does all of its rendering directly in your web browser.

It‚Äôs free: Local rendering eliminates the need for expensive cloud infrastructure, making it possible for us to offer Vizzy for free
You‚Äôre in control: Whether you want to render a video with a custom resolution, or wildly inefficient settings, we won‚Äôt stop you - after all, it‚Äôs your computer
No internet, no problem: Even if your internet connection cuts out mid-render, since our editor runs on your computer, it will just continue the process

Vizzy leverages the power of modern web technologies, which allow it to do complex calculations and rendering right in your browser, without involving a powerful remote server.
Cloud-based storage
We still employ a cloud infrastructure to make your experience using the editor better:

Project files: Your projects are automatically uploaded to our servers when you save them
Asset storage: Any project assets you upload into the project are also saved to our servers
Creations: If you choose to publish your project to the Creations page, others can view and remix it



                  
                  Did you know? 
                  
                

The Media tab allows you to upload files that can be referenced across many projects, saving us some storage costs!


Monetization

We are using advertisement spots on Vizzy to cover our server costs
We accept donations from our generous community
We do not sell your data1



                  
                  Disable your ad blocker! 
                  
                

We rely on ads to sustain our service. If we do not get enough ad revenue, we will not be able to offer Vizzy for free anymore


Footnotes


See our privacy policy ‚Ü©

Introduction/System-Requirements.title: System Requirements
Introduction/System-Requirements.content:
üíª System Requirements
Vizzy is designed to run well on a wide range of modern computers, but performance will depend on factors like your computer‚Äôs specifications, project complexity, resolution and others


                  
                  Warning! 
                  
                

Vizzy is a desktop-first application! We do not offer active support for mobile browsers. You are likely to experience crashes and out-of-memory errors using mobile devices


Minimum Requirements

Operating system: Any operating system that supports a modern web browser. This includes Windows, macOS, Linux, and ChromeOS
Browser: We strongly recommend using the latest version of Google Chrome or a Chromium-based browser
Processor: A relatively modern multi-core processor (from the last 5-7 years) is recommended
RAM: At least 4GB of available RAM. 8GB or more is recommended for longer audio files.
Graphics: A dedicated graphics card (GPU) will significantly improve performance, but is not required!
Internet: A stable internet connection is required to load Vizzy and save/load projects if using the online save feature.

Layers/What-is-a-layer.title: What is a layer?
Layers/What-is-a-layer.content:
What is a layer?
Layers are objects in Vizzy through which items are rendered to the screen or to a buffer.
highlight
Layer types
There are two layer types in Vizzy - 2D and 3D (Orthographic and Perspective), we might also call them camera types. The camera type is automatically selected based on the first item you add to the layer, but you can always change it by clicking the layer.
Orthographic
Layers using the orthographic projection use parallel lines to project an outline to a plane. Effectively, this means that objects within the camera‚Äôs clip plane will be the same size
Perspective
Layers using the perspective projection will simulate how the human eye or a camera see perspective, i.e. objects further away will appear smaller


Image credit1

Transform controls
Each layer has something called transform controls.

These controls are none other than the controls for the layer‚Äôs camera. You can place the camera and the items in a layer anywhere in the 3D space


                  
                  Inverted scale 
                  
                

The scale control of the layer is inverted, meaning setting the x scale to 0.5 will scale the objects to twice their original size along that axis, instead of half.


Effects
All layers can have effects added to them.
